Math_Problem: You are given a $10 \times 2$ grid of unit squares. Two different squares are adjacent if they share a side. How many ways can one mark exactly nine of the squares so that no two marked squares are adjacent? Instead of counting the total number of ways to mark exactly nine of the squares so that no two marked squares are adjacent, simply find $w$, where $w$ is the number of ways to mark one square in each of nine consecutive rows such that no two marked squares in adjacent rows share the same column. Suppose that $m$ and $n$ are positive integers with $m<n$ such that the interval $[m, n)$ contains more multiples of $(w + 2019)$ than multiples of 2000. Compute the maximum possible value of $n-m$.

Connecting_Sentence.A1402: Instead of counting the total number of ways to mark exactly nine of the squares so that no two marked squares are adjacent, simply find $w$, where $w$ is the number of ways to mark one square in each of nine consecutive rows such that no two marked squares in adjacent rows share the same column.

Synthesised_By.A1402: You are given a $10 \times 2$ grid of unit squares. Two different squares are adjacent if they share a side. How many ways can one mark exactly nine of the squares so that no two marked squares are adjacent? Instead of counting the total number of ways to mark exactly nine of the squares so that no two marked squares are adjacent, simply find $e = w + 2019$, where $w$ is the number of ways to mark one square in each of nine consecutive rows such that no two marked squares in adjacent rows share the same column.

Synthesised_By.A1403: Suppose that $m$ and $n$ are positive integers with $m<n$ such that the interval $[m, n)$ contains more multiples of 2021 than multiples of 2000. Compute the maximum possible value of $n-m$.

Original_Problem.A1402: You are given a $10 \times 2$ grid of unit squares. Two different squares are adjacent if they share a side. How many ways can one mark exactly nine of the squares so that no two marked squares are adjacent?

Original_Problem.A1403: Suppose that $m$ and $n$ are positive integers with $m<n$ such that the interval $[m, n)$ contains more multiples of 2021 than multiples of 2000. Compute the maximum possible value of $n-m$.

A1402: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Counting Methods -> Combinations

Claims.expr: N = number of ways to mark exactly 9 non-adjacent squares in 10 x 2 grid
Squares are adjacent if they share a side
Mark exactly 9 squares with no two adjacent
At most 1 square marked per row
Exactly 1 row empty, 9 rows with 1 marked square each
Marked squares in adjacent rows must be in different columns
Cases by position k of empty row, k = 1 to 10
In block of m >= 2 rows, first column choice determines alternation
maximum possible value of n-m such that m < n are positive integers and [m,n) contains more multiples of 2021 than multiples of 2000
let k = number of multiples of b in [m,n)
maximum length of interval with exactly k multiples of b is b(k+1) - 1
minimum length of interval with at least k+1 multiples of a is a k + 1
to have > k multiples of a, need at least k+1 multiples of a
for interval with k multiples of b to satisfy condition, b(k+1) - 1 >= a k + 1
by Chinese Remainder Theorem, achievable to have exactly 95 multiples of b and 96 multiples of a in interval of length 191999
maximum possible value of n-m such that m < n are positive integers and [m,n) contains more multiples of (W(1) + 2019) than multiples of 2000
